title: 112_hr1221
content: The Act may be cited as the "Equity in Government Compensation Act of 2011". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress found that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, privately owned but publicly chartered Government-sponsored enterprises, were central to the 2008 financial crisis. Their failures led to the deepest economic decline since World War II, resulting in the Bush Administration placing them in conservatorship in September 2008. In September 2008, the Bush Administration established a $200 billion facility to purchase senior preferred stock in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. In February 2009, the Obama Administration raised the stock purchase commitment to $400 billion. By Christmas Eve 2009, the Obama Administration removed limits on Federal funds to cover losses, resulting in taxpayers owning nearly 80% of the two GSEs. The Congressional Budget Office concluded that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have effectively become Government-owned entities. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, now government entities, are expected to be a long-term burden on taxpayers due to market conditions and political mandates. Despite this, the Treasury Department and FHFA approved excessive compensation packages for their CEOs in 2009-2011. The FHFA approved multi-million dollar cash compensation packages for top executives of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, excluding bonuses and long-term incentives for 2008. The Strategic Plan includes a commitment to operate the GSEs safely and soundly. The FHFA can withhold executive compensation payments for review under the Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The term "employee" refers to an employee of an enterprise, excluding prevailing rate employees. The term "enterprise" includes the Federal National Mortgage Association, its affiliates, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and its affiliates. The term "executive officer" has the same meaning as in section 1303(12). The term "executive officer" has the same meaning as in section 1303(12) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992. SEC. 4. REASONABLE PAY FOR EXECUTIVE OFFICERS. The Director shall suspend approved 2011 compensation packages for executive officers of an enterprise and establish a new compensation system. Executive officers should return 2010 and 2011 compensation if their packages are suspended. The Secretary of the Treasury requires executive officers to return excess compensation earned in 2010 and 2011. Any returned amounts will be used to reduce the national debt. Executive officers of enterprises are also subject to limitations on compensation. Executive officers of enterprises whose compensation package is suspended shall not be compensated more than the highest compensated employee of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. SEC. 5. COMPENSATION RATE OF EMPLOYEES OF FANNIE MAE AND FREDDIE MAC. During federal charter periods under specific acts, employee compensation must comply with this section. The Director will adjust the basic compensation rate for current employees to align with the General Schedule. The Director will adjust employee compensation rates to align with the General Schedule, increasing rates to the minimum if below, equalizing if already at the appropriate grade, and adjusting if between two rates. The Director will adjust employee compensation rates to align with the General Schedule, increasing rates to the minimum if below, equalizing if already at the appropriate grade, and adjusting if between two rates. If an employee's compensation is below the appropriate grade, it will be increased. If it is between two rates, the higher rate will apply. If compensation exceeds the maximum rate, it will be reduced to that maximum rate. The General Schedule will adjust compensation rates for positions and employees, not considered transfers or promotions. Employees with earned but uncredited compensation increases will receive credit before their rates are adjusted. The General Schedule adjusts compensation rates for positions and employees, not transfers or promotions. Employees with uncredited compensation increases will receive credit before their rates are adjusted. Each employee's service since their last compensation increase is considered for their first step increase under the General Schedule. An increase in basic compensation due to the enactment of the adjustment shall not be equivalent to step increases for other employees. New employees starting after the enactment of this Act will have their grade and pay fixed according to the General Schedule. SEC. 6 states that executive officers or employees affected by sections 4 and 5 are not considered Federal employees.
